child.publications: Healey, Alan & David D Thomas. 1962. Some Philippine Language Subgroupings: A Lexicostatistical Study, Anthropological Linguistics, no. 9 edn., vol. 4, 21-33. Bloomington: Indiana University.

child.pub-comments: “...the average of these comparisons [of the Southern Philippine languages] is 40.5%, corresponding to a time depth of 2100 years, that is, a divergence of the branches of the Southern Philippine Family at about 100 B.C. The internal unity of the Visayan branch […], the Davaweño branch […], the Maranao-Magindanao branch, and the Manobo branch […] is demonstrated by intra-branch comparisons, all of which lie within the range 60-70% probable shared cognates” (Thomas and Healey 1962:25).

child.publications: Healey, Alan & David D Thomas. 1962. Some Philippine Language Subgroupings: A Lexicostatistical Study, Anthropological Linguistics, no. 9 edn., vol. 4, 21-33. Bloomington: Indiana University.
child.pub-comments: “The position of Pangasinan is uncertain. It may be regarded as another language family which diverged at the same time as the Northern Philippine Family and Southern Philippine Family, and which later received loans from both Sambal and Inibaloi. (This interpretation is adopted in the 'family tree' in section 0 of the present paper.) Alternatively, Pangasinan may be regarded either as a fourth branch of the Northern Philippine Family which has borrowed from Sambal, or as an eleventh branch of the Southern Philippine Family which has borrowed from Inibaloi” (Thomas and Healey 1962:31).

child.pub-comments: “The internal unity of the Ilocano-Cagayan branch […] is rather loose knit, with intra-branch comparisons ranging from 44% to about 60%” (Thomas and Healey 1962:25).

child.publications: Healey, Alan & David D Thomas. 1962. Some Philippine Language Subgroupings: A Lexicostatistical Study, Anthropological Linguistics, no. 9 edn., vol. 4, 21-33. Bloomington: Indiana University.

child.pub-comments: “Nine languages belonging to the Northern Philippine Family have been compared with each other and the results indicate a simultaneous split into two branches: Inibaloi-Mountain Province, Ilocano-Cagayan” (Thomas and Healey 1962: 24).

“The average of these comparisons [of the Northern Philippine and Southern Philippine languages] is 30.9% which corresponds to a time depth of 2690 years, that is, a divergence of the Northern Philippine Family and Southern Philippine Family at about 700 B.C.” (Thomas and Healey 1962:24).

child.publications: Healey, Alan & David D Thomas. 1962. Some Philippine Language Subgroupings: A Lexicostatistical Study, Anthropological Linguistics, no. 9 edn., vol. 4, 21-33. Bloomington: Indiana University.
Healey, Alan & David D Thomas. 1962. Some Philippine Language Subgroupings: A Lexicostatistical Study, Anthropological Linguistics, no. 9 edn., vol. 4, 21-33. Bloomington: Indiana University.
child.pub-comments: “Ilongot appears to have diverged from all the other languages before the divergence of the Northern Philippine Family and the Southern Philippine Family, the figures showing a minimum comparison of about 31%. There is some evidence of borrowing from Ilongot by the whole Northern Philippine Family” (Thomas and Healey 1962:31).

child.publications: Healey, Alan & David D Thomas. 1962. Some Philippine Language Subgroupings: A Lexicostatistical Study, Anthropological Linguistics, no. 9 edn., vol. 4, 21-33. Bloomington: Indiana University.

child.pub-comments: “...the average of these comparisons [of the Philippine Stock languages] is 27.0%, corresponding to a time depth of 3020 years, that is, a divergence around 1100 B.C.” (Thomas and Healey 1962:26).

child.pub-comments: Thomas and Healey (1962:22) state that Tiruray is “probably” part of the Southern Mindanao Family.

child.pub-comments: According to Thomas and Healey (1962:27), Malay has the status of a lingua franca, which influences the surrounding languages through “considerable borrowing.”
child.codes: zlm, abs, btj, mhp, bpq, bve, bvu, coa, jax, meo, mqg, mkn, lrt, mfp, xmm, max, mfa, msi, zsm, vkt

child.pub-comments: “But it does seem to be fairly clear evidence that Chamic and Malay belong to the same group as against the Philippines and against Southern Mindanaoan. This grouping we will tentatively call the Malay Stock” (Thomas and Healey 1962:27).

root.pub-comments: Thomas and Healey (1962:22) describes the following tree as “tentative.” While mention of “Proto-Indonesian” is rather ambiguous in the article, since it is the highest subgrouping mentioned by the authors, it has been included here as the parent node. “Probably around 1300 B.C. some larger grouping (which may well prove to be a sizeable part of Proto-Indonesian) split into the Philippine Superstock, the Southern Mindanao Family (Bilaan, Tagabili, and probably Tiruray), and a stock including Malay and the Chamic Family of Viet Nam. It still remains to be seen whether any of the languages of Borneo, Celebes, western Micronesia, or Formosa belong to the Philippine Superstock, or whether their relationship to the Philippine Stock is more remote” (Thomas and Healey 1962:22).
